title: Dissolving Futures
segmentation: Hello, I'd just like to thank future architecture and all the organizers for inviting me and very happy to be here and to meet with all the other participants learning a lot.
So I'm going to show you a series of images.
These are photos that I've taken.
And then I'll explain the project.
But my project is called Disolving futures.
So these are not manipulated.
They're just straight photos.

So in the age of image proliferation, the representation of architecture is taking the place in our collective imaginations once occupied by architecture itself, the visual impact of urban skylines and facades is being subsumed by the omnipresence of the city's image.
This is evidenced in ever increasing tendencies to look at images on portable screens while negotiating the urban environment, but it is also making the built space itself as speculative.

It is also marking the built space itself, so it's not just that we're looking at screens, but we're seeing it in the city itself, in the urban landscape as speculative practices accelerate urban transformation, the city adorns itself in images of what it is to become, so those were some of the images I just showed you.
Despective the speculative transformation never fully attained.
These images linger and fade, dissolving into a ruptured matrix of urban decay, an unfinished potential.
Rather than so my project.
Rather than reflecting on what architecture could be, I reflect on what the future is becoming and for me that's faded imprints of spectacular promises.
Perhaps that's what it's becoming so.
This is an ongoing project I started over 10 years ago.
It's over 1000 pictures I've taken and about 100 of these so far have been.
I've selected to use.
Pictures been taken, sort of in four different countries, in four different continents.
It's a spontaneous wandering process.
It isn't an archive, or it's not.
It's not.
It's not.
It's not an exhaustive study of the font phenomenon, but it's rather the results of a process of coming across these sites.

As I traverse urban environments, they catch my eye, which they are designed to do, but I think there's a certain they resonate with me when I see them, and perhaps as embodiments of what these this morning called an unknown known.
There's something about them that.
I know, but I don't know why I know it.
So it's.
So as many parts there many I haven't.
I've got this collection and I'm sort of trying to work out how to how to use them and what I'm proposing.
Here is an installation with the images projected in a continuous dissolve sequence.
And so.
Where does the dissolve sequence come from?
Well, I was reading.
I've recently been reading HG Wells.
The shape of things to come.

I think we're talking about futures here and he was a futurist or this certainly this book is a futurist and it's an interesting book to read now as somebody in the 1930s looking towards that I'm wearing now and projecting another different future.
But this is a quotation from the book.

This is something I found the book when he was looking backwards or the book sort of looks back from an imaginary future, but he reflects back to the 19th century and he says in the middle years of the 19th century there was a primitive form of entertainment in Western Europe and America called dissolving views.
Crudely colored pictures were thrown on screen by double barreled arrangement of lenses called a magic Lantern.
A picture would be rejected first by the right hand lens of the contraption.
Then the light would be shifted to the left hand side.

So the picture cast by 1/2 of the apparatus faded as the other became brighter, the real became a Phantom and vanished, and the faint intimations of successor became at length the only reality visible, visible.
And so this last sentence.
So that sums up what I'm seeing with these with these kind of projected images, figuratively protected images in the city of a future.
It tends to subsume what was there before an what.
What I realized when I read this, 'cause I knew about the Magic Lanterns.
This is yet it was that I always somehow I've worked a lot with media and film and video.

I always assume this dissolve effect, which is where you one images fades into another was was a cinematic kind of device, but in fact what I realized in wells is history was that it was something that that effect was something that existed before cinema existed.
So we already had a memory of that effect of one image dissolving into another and becoming another the moving picture.
Wasn't was invented later in the later in the century.
So we had that in our kind of collective consciousness, I think.
This is the end of, well, this text.
Apparently this is where ancestors found the magic effect at a certain phase.
It must have been hard to determine which details were advancing and which were receding realities or of any part of the.

Or of any part of the assembly, whether it was real, it was very much after the fashion of this artless Victorian wonder toy, that faith in established institutions and uses usage is faded, and the idea of the modern state dawned upon the intelligence of mankind.
So he sees this kind of palimpsest of one image fading to another as a kind of because it goes on, and I'm not going to quote it, but it goes on as a kind of pre figuring of a modern moment where.
These dissolving views presented prefigured in nascent.
Yeah, they presented a nascent modern political formation that dissolved and blended the established institutions of Imperial Europe.

And perhaps this dissolving views that I collect because I see them as kind of dissolving views that surround contemporary sites of demolition and construction, 'cause we're pretty much now in the city.
Wherever there's construction, there's demolition.
You are a symptom of an ongoing dismantling and reclamation of the modern project, and often it's the modern project as a pastiche of itself.
They sort of rebuild buildings that refer back to modernism.
So this is just an image of the how the Magic Lantern functions.
So you see there's this is actually one with three lenses, so that you can.
You can fate.
You can fade out one and fade in another so they can blend one to the other.
Letting us there's a date on this is.
Wasn't ridiculous 18 something I was.
It was Ward Ward 1884 so again that's before.
The projected films of Lumiere in 1895.

So then this maybe think of a text that was written by Sigmund Freud in a letter to his family from Rome, which was quote which I read in a book quoted, read a book by Jonathan Crary's suspensions of Perception.
And because this is relating it directly, this Magic Lantern view back to architecture and the transformation of architecture in the beginning of the nine beginning of the 20th century.
And it's an architecture being transformed by the projected image, which is something we sort of see's.

Uh, at least there's been a lot of recent developments of this in the past 20 years, particularly, maybe in North America in Asia, where image buildings are being projected on and the architecture is being transformed into sort of moving image projection, but.
This was already happening in.
Beginning of the 20th century on so this is what Freud wrote in a letter to his family on the pizza Kelowna behind which I'm staying.
As you know, several 1000 people congregate every night.

The evening air is really delicious in Rome, wind is hardly known behind the column is a stand for military band which plays there every night and on the roof of a house at the other end of the odds that there is a screen on which associate associate a Italiana projects Lantern slides.
They're actually advertisements, but a big all the public.
These are.

Interspersed with pictures of landscapes of the Congo, Glaciere sense and so on, but since these wouldn't be enough, the boredom is interrupted by short cinematographic performances for the sake of which the old children, your father included, suffer quietly, the advertisements and monotonous photographs.
And query says about this.

The Magic Lantern slides the cinematic projections, and the electrically lit advertisements are only the more obvious elements of a formless field of attraction, which undermines the older monumental organization of the city square.

It's defining architectural facades and a central Imperial, column with its own images, remote Roman victories over German types give way to the evanescent Lantern scenes of modern day colonies and foreign landscapes.
So Freud saw the formless field of the Magic Lantern projections as evoking the spatialized idealized exotica colonial distance.

The spectacle of temporary publicity that surrounds and interacts with sites of urban instruction and demolition of Oak set for me that opens, looks at temporal, exotic, and I idealize promise of a future space that exists above and beyond the constraints and rigors of the urban everyday.
So both of them are sort of fictions that they're proposing.
And likewise, likewise, while these billboards and hoardings lock the formlessness.
The floating instability of the Lantern projections.
They also lack the temporal and maybe domestic or social stability of the build space they promise.
They function is unreliable mind stones.
Milestones in the urban landscape temporarily marking a site for an undetermined.
The billboards are changing depending on the project's development, and many disappear without the project ever being realized, so they're they're not.
They're not like a cinematic projection that has a short duration and sort of flickers, but they're not.
They're not stable like architecture either, because they'll be there for as long as their project is being developed, or they might be taken down the next day, so they can't.
They can't really function as markers in the urban landscape.
I'm not going to say this, 'cause it's already said.
I who am I?
I'm not an architect, I'm an artist.
I engage in an artistic practice that explores architectural and urban space.
It's an exploration that is translated into time based images installed within in responding to interior architectural exhibition spaces.
So for awhile, I've been practicing this.
We're looking at architecture outside and bring it in to an interior architectural space.
In responding to that space as well.
So it's sort of an architecture within architecture.
The space of the city and its architectures are scrutinized through their seemingly insignificant details.
Abandoned or underused buildings, older model cars deserted streets.
Details that resonate as markers of changed changing and forgetting and and in this case well I think I'm I'm exploring the future so I'm following up a future that's possessed in these buildings.
A future of architecture as it dissolves into the present as it stops being a future and just becomes part of the everyday.
And these are just some images of my work.
I'm not going to.
I'm not going to explain it to you there on my website.
If you want more information but just to show you the bit the way I.
My work looks.
Or some of my work looks in installations in installations, and the most of these are all.
Moving image installations.
So there's sort of images of architecture within architecture.
And the last is actually it's a slide dissolve installation of a courtyard projected into a office type space.
So.
I'm just going to finish with a.
Short video 'cause I think it's important to see how so so this notion of dissolves is already there in these images, because this one is 1 architecture being replaced by another.
But there's also I'm also proposing to present it, and I'm not sure how I do this.
At yeah in this plan, yeah, so I'm proposing.
Proposing to present it as a series of.
Dissolving images, so just it, I think this gives you a bit of an idea of how they should blend one into the other.
